Mr.
ROBERT L.
LYNCH (President and Chief Executive Officer, Americans for the Arts): Great to be here.
Leslie, I'm going to begin with you.
The stimulus package allocated $50 million for the National Endowment for the Arts.
Do you think that will be enough?
That is a beginning; it's an important beginning, and it is a recognition that Obama believes in the arts, in the importance of the arts.

So, we are, of course, always looking for more, but we are ever so grateful that we have been recognized with what I would like to think of as some important seed money to begin this new process of establishing the arts in the forefront of America.
Well, Bob, in these tough economic times, some would say that the arts should be low on the list of institutions that need funding.
When compared to health care, joblessness and the war, how can funding for the arts compete as necessary when we're in a recession?
Well, those people who would say that don't really quite understand the role of the arts in America, because the arts are a part of the driving economic force.
Some - over four percent of the businesses in America are arts-related businesses, and 100,000 nonprofit arts organizations out there creating a $166 billion economic impact, 5.7 million jobs.

So, on the jobs front, there's really important information, but at the same time, a lot of the work of the arts connects to things like community development, downtown revitalization, health issues, hospital improvement and on and on - the data is all there - better education, retention rates, youth at risk improved.
So, what we have to do in the arts is make a better case and an ongoing case of what is actually obvious if people just look around.

Well, Leslie, some people oppose government funding of the arts because they oppose tax dollars going to controversial artists like Andres Serrano, who infamously photographed a crucifix in urine in the 1980s.
Is that a legitimate concern, given the climate that we're in?
No, I don't think it's a legitimate concern.
But I think what we have to recognize is that we are now in a new era, and we need very important new problem solvers, and artists are abstract thinkers.

The idea of choosing an Andres Serrano, who supposedly provoked the society with his choice of subject matter, does not talk to the real issue, which is that we need abstract thinkers, right-brain thinkers, creative thinkers, to create new solutions to new problems, because the old issues, the old models, have not worked.

And it is time for us to use all the resources of this country, and we have not looked to the artists, the artistic community, to help us solve and create the country that Obama and the rest of America and the world is looking to see realized.
You know, Bob, Leslie raises an interesting point.
Isn't art best supported from the ground up, like the kind of grassroots political movements that swept Barack Obama into office - community galleries, theaters and the like?
Well, I think what's important to understand is that is the way it's supported.

You take a look at those 100,000 nonprofit arts organizations that I mentioned and the Americans for the Arts tracks, and you'll see that half their money comes from earned income; that's people like you and me paying to come to something or buying something from them.
Another 40 percent of their money comes from private donations; mostly individuals, again, like you and me.
And the final 10 percent is government money, but most of that is local government money investing in advancing the arts locally.
The federal money is a tiny piece, less than a percentage of one percent.
But it's a lever that actually helps create a flow of all the other dollars that creates this wonderful $166 billion nonprofit industry.
How does, Leslie, the - America stack up globally in terms of its government support for the arts?
I'm thinking now just of the story in today's paper about how upset China is over the auctioning off of some sculptures that were in the possession of the late Yves St. Laurent.
Well, we have to recognize that America is the youngest country on the face of the Earth and that America is an amalgam of so many other cultures.

And because as America was structuring itself, it did not have the same kind of structuring system wherein the arts were prioritized as in the other cultures globally, which have a legacy back to ancestral times, where arts was the priority in life to maintain the integrity and the heritage and the character of that culture, of that civilization.

So, now that - as we build America to be the civilization, to be the global power that we envision ourselves to be, and to be part of the global network, we have to also pay equal homage to our artists, who are so important in establishing the criteria for who we are and how we will be leaders and partners in solving the global crisis.
Well, Bob, which segments of the arts tend to be supported most - music, visual arts, performing arts - and why?

Well, you know - and before I jump in on that, I'd just say that the other thing, comparing us internationally, is that our system is completely different than all the other systems, which are largely government supported.
Ours is not a support system; it's an incentive system.
And a little more incentive and you would see massive additional blossoming of private donation and individual support.
Now, the kinds of art forms that get supported, sometimes you see more money going into the kinds of things that have facilities.
It doesn't matter what the art form is- it could be music; it could be theater; it could be dance - but facility investment tends to end up being a chunk of dollars that takes away.
And sometimes on the other end of the spectrum, the art forms that don't require a lot of materials - let's say, like poetry, for example - get less.
But across the board, it really is a community decision.
I just was in Los Angeles, San Jose, San Francisco, New York, and I'm headed up to Nevada this week; each of these places emphasizes different things in their own particular community-arts portfolio.
And I think that's the beauty of the American system.

Here's my final question, and our segment is coming to an end - I appreciate both of you coming on and sharing your thoughts with us - is it fair to suggest that President Obama's approach to the arts is a positive one and that it, in some ways, differs or improves upon that of his predecessor, George Bush?
Leslie?
Like the Kouachi brothers, the men thought to be behind the magazine attack, they were being watched by authorities, but they didn't think they were a threat.
We actually skate on October 10th at Skate South.

Well, I think that what we had witnessed from the inauguration, even from the outset during his campaigning, and certainly just recently, the other night, in awarding Stevie Wonder one of the most cherished awards, is that he is building on the tradition and legacy and he is clearly going to expand the legacy of how a presidential positioning will enhance and partner with the arts to build a nation and to reinforce all of those things that we hope to see move - to enhance our understanding of how the arts improved the quality of life in this country.
All right, our time is out.
I appreciate both of you for appearing with us.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.

Bob Lynch is the president and CEO of Americans for the Arts; he joined us from NPR headquarters in Washington; and Leslie King-Hammond is the director of the Center for Race and Culture and dean emeritus of graduate studies at Maryland Institute College of Art.
The FBI is opening a domestic terrorist investigation into the shooting last week at California's Gilroy Garlic Festival.
They say the gunman was exploring violent ideologies, though he left no manifesto.
However, the man responsible for the El Paso shooting does seem to have posted a lengthy manifesto online.
Turns out, that's typical for mass shooters.
And often, these so-called manifestos use similar racist language.
And they're posted to the same Internet communities.
I talked with Patrick Blanchfield of the Brooklyn Institute for Social Research and asked him what we can learn from these.
There is a point at which what these acts are speak for themselves.
The body count, the people who were targeted, that is in many ways far more expressive and politically (ph) urgent, just as a transaction of power, than things people write and do.
Then why do they write them?
Then why do these mass murderers feel compelled to leave a statement?
It's definitely the case that many of these people are seeking a sort of ephemeral notoriety and longer term memorialization in fetid subcultures on the Internet.

But another thing - and this is, I think, the thing we have to keep in mind when we talk about these acts and the speech that's sort of attached to them - is that our discourse has a way of laundering away the obviousness of what these things are.
We try to ask these ultimately unknowable questions, right?
What was this person's ultimate intentions?
Where did they go wrong, right?
And that has a way of centering not just their own individual, unknowable black box interiority but our own position as spectators and consumers of information.
And again, that is understandable.
Believe me, I read these all the time.
And you feel the existential tug where you want to know, how could someone do this?
And there must be something.
If we only read between the lines, if we only more closely examined these statements that we could somehow find answers.
Precisely.
But I keep on coming back to how - in the case of the El Paso mass shooting in particular - right?
- where the alleged manifesto's extremely clear about how the shooter wanted to target Latinx people - right?

- in the wake of that, there are consistent reports that the count of the wounded may actually be much higher because a lot of people who were hurt are afraid to seek medical care because of their undocumented status.
And I want to stress, they got the message.
So do you believe the media is making a mistake by even reporting the content of these statements?
No, I want to be clear here - right?
- that I think we need, obviously, to talk in sophisticated and intelligent ways about what is clearly a decentralized, long-standing movement of what you could call political terror.

At the same time, the fact that these things keep happening and the fact that we find ourselves asking the same questions suggests that there're probably some other questions we should be asking that we don't want to be asking.
Like what?

Well, what's the point of interface between what these people say their reasons are and also what their actions do and what we accept more broadly as normative, acceptable expressions and differences of, quote-unquote, ""opinion in the public sphere?"" And once you get very granularly into what these manifestos say - right?
- and there's a whole repertoire of tropes involving ethnic replacement, involving a fixation on birth rates, white birth rates - right?
- involving a fixation on invaders coming through our southern borders...
Statements we have heard from our political leaders, in particular this president in some cases.
Precisely.

But also, when you read this person talk about how elites support, quote, ""open borders, free health care for illegals, citizenship and more to enact a political coup"" - yeah, I hear Trump there, but the moment he also starts talking about real Americans, about the future of the West, about American birth rates, I also hear a lot of stuff that I read better written, more sophisticated, more, quote-unquote, ""intellectual"" in the op-ed pages of The New York Times, in The Wall Street Journal.
There's a tremendous overlap here.
To be clear, I'm not assigning unicausal, moral responsibility of point A to point B to the president, to columnists, et cetera.
But there is a way in which what these people do and what they say underscore things that we have normalized and made acceptable.
And they give it back to us.
And the people who are targets hear the message.
They're killed, and they flee.
And meanwhile, the rest of us will adopt this almost naive, kind of childlike wonder - where could this possibly have come from?
You're saying there is danger in treating these manifestos as fringe exceptionalism.
There are a lot of features to these manifestos.
Like, they all think they're smarter than they are, right?
They're written at, basically, at the levels like a poor, undergraduate, first-year freshmen comp essay, right?

But there's something about the very clunkiness and cheapness and tawdriness and generic character of it that once you see it and you look back, you're like, oh, people get paid six figures to say the exact same things.
But, you know, they'll more abstractly talk about the future of the West or generational decline or reinvigorating America.
It's a question of how we normalize, frankly, toxic expressions of American identity and how normal that is.
And that's the flip side of how abnormal these events seem.
Right.

The bottom line being these statements tell us far less about the individuals who carry out these crimes and write these screeds than they do about the culture that bred these individuals in the first place.
That's absolutely right.

And I think until we're willing to talk about how systematically there is an interface between those two things, we're just going to develop an evermore sophisticated, fundamentally navel-gazing repertoire of gestures of deferral and disavowal and specious false distinctions.
And that's not going to stop this.
Patrick Blanchfield of the Brooklyn Institute for Social Research, thank you so much for your time.
Absolutely.
